captions.text:
In order for us to see something, it either
needs to emit light directly (like the sun

or a lightbulb filament or firefly) or else
have photons of light bounce off of it and
into our eyes.

But how do we see light itself? You can't
bounce light off of light (just like you can't

bounce slinky waves or ripples in the water
off of each other - they just pass right through!),

plus, if you "look" at a photon of light in
the normal everyday way, that means your eye

or camera or photodetector will absorb it
- and then it's gone. Destroyed! Annihilated!

It's like if you want to test how much weight
a bridge can support before it falls down…

once you've done your measurement, you have
the information you wanted but you no longer
have a bridge.

So in order to "see" light, we need to use
non-destructive testing.

One way of doing that is to make a super dark,
super cold box and cover the inside with a

really really shiny mirror - a mirror so excellently
reflective that photons of light bounce back

and forth more than a BILLION times before
being absorbed. In that time, they'll travel
a distance equivalent to one trip around earth.

This box is also so cold and dark that only
occasionally will there even be one photon

inside. And if there is one, how do we tell
without destroying it?

Well, we send an atom through the box, an
atom in a superposition of two different atomic

states, just like Schrödinger's cat! If there's
no photon inside the mirror box, then when

the atom comes out the other side, we'll most
likely measure it as being in a certain one

of the states - let's call it "dead". But
if there is a photon in there, and we carefully

send the atom through so it doesn't actually
destroy the photon, the atom-photon interactions

changes the odds - so now it's an overwhelming
chance that we see that atom as "alive." After

sending through a few atoms, if they're mainly
in the "alive" state, then we know there's

a photon in the box! And if they're "dead":
no photon.

It's kind of like sending a pinwheel through
a dark chamber, and if it comes out the other

side spinning, you know the wind is blowing.
If not? No wind.

In fact, once we know there's a photon in
there, we can use this cat measurement technique

to measure and manipulate other things about
the photon: we can see how long it bounces

back and forth before it gets absorbed, check
if it's in a superposition and even force

it into a superposition like Schrödinger's
cat itself - so, not only can we see light,

we can now use Schrödinger's cat to measure
Schrödinger's cat: Quantum Catception!

title: 2012 Nobel Prize: How Do We See Light?

comments.author: Samm Sheperd (SNRS)

comments.text:
+Aqw tinyente This is where relativity comes in to play. The total mass of 
a particle in motion comes partly from the mass of the particle itself 
known as the rest mass (which is what the particle would 'weigh' if it 
wasn't moving) and partly from the mass equivalent of the energy of motion 
given by e=mc^2, known as inertial mass. Since it takes more energy to move 
a heavy object than a light object, inertial mass is proportional to both 
the rest mass and the speed of an object. Thus the more massive an object 
is, the more energy is required to accelerate it, therefore the more mass 
it has. It turns out that this is a vicious circle that prevents objects 
with any rest mass at all from ever reaching the speed of light. Or to look 
at it another way, the lower the rest mass the faster you can make it go, 
hence the fastest things in the universe are those objects with zero rest 
mass, which happens to be the speed of light because we've named the speed 
of light after the speed of a zero rest mass particle, a photon of light. 
The neutrino is also a zero rest mass particle and guess what it; travels 
at the speed of light too! There is one part of this I don't understand 
though, I've often heard it said that massless particles are compelled to 
travel at the speed of light, but never heard an explanation as to why in 
layman's terms.

comments.author: bracken pops

comments.text:
+bracken pops When you go at the speed of light (which is impossible), time 
stops for you. According to relativity, if you travel billions of light 
years at the speed of light, it will seem instant for you.

You can also think about this like that : it is impossible to go faster 
than the speed of light because when you get near the speed of light, going 
faster and faster does not increase you speed anymore, but it causes the 
space to bend (shrink) before you, so the distances decrease. If you manage 
to reach the speed of light, the whole universe before you would have 
shrunk into nothing. Going at the speed of light is synonym of getting from 
the space and time (and maybe destroy the whole universe?).

I think that in this condition, talking about "instant" or "length" has 
just no meaning. If you consider that "getting up and walk" is an action 
that requires time to proceed, then it is impossible to get up and walk 
when the train goes at the speed of light.

comments.text:
I'll give a try with my limited knowledge. Light has dual characteristics. 
Its both a wave and a particle at the same time. But it is only in the last 
century that this particle nature of the light has been observed.  And the 
light particles are minuscule force carrying "bosonic" particles with zero 
mass and probably zero surface area or volume. So how do we see anything 
with no surface area or volume? We just can't. This brings it to ask 
ourselves with disbelief, "Don't we see light?" Well we think that we "see" 
light but actually we don't . We see things illuminated by light. But we 
can detect light particles using the setup described in the video. We can 
"see" it by measuring its "influence" on the other elementary particles.
comments.author: Samrat Debroy

comments.text:
+Lethargica Stengah It's not actually all that difficult to understand and 
this is the layman's explanation of quantum probability. What it doesn't 
do, is explain "how we see light". 

It definitely talks about how we detect the state of a photon, but again, 
it doesn't explain "how we see light".
The deepness of the question of probability and quantum mechanics is not in 
question.
My issue is that the title says one thing, and the video shows another. 
Period.

However, that is irrelevant. 

This thread is based on you saying "No, it made you aware that it is much 
deeper than you initially thought." and then me responding with "Yeah... 
no. I know what I said and meant it."... do we *really* need to invent

comments.text:
+william sando Yeah, I know about the double-slit experiment, but I'm 
skeptical about a huge portion of what a lot of people refer to as quantum 
physics -- in particular, I do not believe that waves / wave-collapses 
exist or happen at all (based on a lack of observable, falsifiable 
evidence). I think energy (and thus particles) can definitely behave like 
waves when measured in certain ways, but those behaviors can be explained 
classically. Even crazy stuff like parallel processing and algorithmic 
aggregation in computing can be explained with classical mechanics (via 
classical computation): Consider the idea of a torrent, or the way 
distributed computing works. All of these processes were once thought to be 
only possible with a "quantum computer" -- now proven possible with really 
expensive classical computers. I wonder if with enough [relevant] fidelity, 
the double-slit experiment would lose its luster like the quantum computer; 
specifically following the full realization that the language surrounding 
the double-slit experiment inspires some serious misinformation.
comments.author: Benny Schmidt

comments.text:

comments.text:
+Benny Schmidt The wave function isn't like a wave in space, its a 
mathematical equation which measures the probability of a certain particle 
being at certain spots and velocities, once you measure the particle the 
wave function collapses because the probability is now 1 for the measured 
configuration. (I think)
comments.author: arithine

comments.text:
+william sando If the wave function cannot be measured (without 
collapsing), then how do you have proof that a wave exists in the quantum 
sense? In other words, why not just assume that waves don't exist and there 
are only particles?
comments.author: Benny Schmidt

comments.text:
No it has nothing to do with sentience. Observation just means taking a 
measurement, which is usually done using a Photon (as it's a single, tiny 
unit that can convey information to us). The problem is that, the Quantum 
system is so fragile that taking that measurement with the Photon 
inevitably causes a state change (because the wave function collapses). So 
we have no ability to measure the quantum state before it collapses because 
our only way to measure it causes it to collapse. I'm no Physics student, 
but that's how I understand it anyway.
comments.author: william sando

comments.text:
+Victor Kyrg "it is impossible at ANY time to justify the belief of the sun 
rising tomorrow, based on even millennia of sun rises: seeing a million of 
something, does not exclude that the million-and-first sun won't rise (or 
is a blue sun, or a square, etc.). In formal terms: Induction is at all 
times invalid."

Kind of depends on what epistemology you are using, yes?

I am by no means going to say that you are entirely wrong, as it is 
possible for the sun not to rise tomorrow, but statistically unlikely. If 
you use evidentialism as the basis for what makes a belief valid you would 
be justified in believing the sun will rise tomorrow, or arguably even that 
the world outside my brain "exists" based on just the sheer amount of 
evidence. Of course I could be wrong about either of those two propositions 
but belief using evidentialism is not a black and white deal, so when I say 
I believe the sun will rise tomorrow I really am saying that I am 99.99999 
percent sure the sun will rise tomorrow, and with the existence of the 
outside world I would probably say I am 95 percent sure.
comments.author: arithine

comments.text:
"Observer" has become a loaded term.
It has nothing to do with sentience. It just means there's been an 
interaction or, in the case of an experiment, a measurement performed.

For example, hitting a small particle (A) with a different particle (B); 
you know the what the 'A' particle was doing before you hit it, because you 
can measure the new angle and momentum of 'B.' But, since you hit 'A,' you 
changed 'A's' momentum and direction.

"Using a fancy term"

comments.author: MomoTheBellyDancer

comments.text:
+MomoTheBellyDancer Using a fancy term doesn't count as an argument that 
justifies your position, mate. It's not a matter of opinion that our 
inferences are irrational: no matter how many millions of years the sun has 
come up everyday, you can not claim it will do so tomorrow with a 100% 
certainty -- just can't be justified. There's always a chance larger than 
zero that it won't. Period.

That is because inference as reasoning is irrational: you cannot conclude 
that a certain observation is a law of nature, just because it occurs 
often. Just because every swan is white, doesn't mean all swans are 
necessarily white at all times at any point in the future. Same goes for 
everything else: seeing patterns is not the same as justifying your beliefs 
regarding them.

So yes: I too expect the sun to come up tomorrow, just like anyone else -- 
but I'm not justified at all, because there is a chance larger than 0 that 
it won't. It's reasonable, but it's not rational.

To top it off: claiming that you ARE justified in believing such 
'predictions' is implicitly based on the belief that nature is uniform -- 
that nature will NEVER break its own laws -- which again is an inference 
and thus an irrational circle of argument.

Believe what you want, but don't think it's justified at all times just 
because you feel it is.
comments.author: Victor Kyrg

comments.text:
+Victor Kyrg

"That's debatable at the very least."

No, it's not. The moon is a macroscopic object. Don't be stupid.
comments.author: MomoTheBellyDancer

comments.text:
+jhon Me That's debatable at the very least. People forget that our 
knowledge (and therefore science) are based on several debatable premisses, 
one of which being that the world is real -- real meaning that it exists 
regardless of whether someone's there to see it.

The thing is that EVERYONE acts on the belief the world is real: we all 
expect the sun to come up tomorrow -- and for millennia, it has seemed to 
be justified: it came up every single day. Experience seems to give us 
predictive powers. However, rationally, it cannot be justified at all:

1 - there is always a chance that is not zero that the sun actually won't 
come up tomorrow. It probably will, as it has always done, but there will 
always be the possibility it doesn't -- for whatever reason there may be.

2 - and that possibility makes the irrationality of it all: it is 
impossible at ANY time to justify the belief of the sun rising tomorrow, 
based on even millennia of sun rises: seeing a million of something, does 
not exclude that the million-and-first sun won't rise (or is a blue sun, or 
a square, etc.). In formal terms: Induction is at all times invalid.

So again: it's used by everyone, and it seems to work every time (!), but 
prediction is rationally never justified. It's the paradox of science, and 
knowledge in general, and what's kept philosophers awake at night since 
(and perhaps even before) 400-something B.C.
comments.author: Victor Kyrg

comments.author: natemcgraw

comments.text:
There is a photoreceptor in your eye called rhodopsin which is a 
combination of a protein called opsin and a pigment called retinal. When 
light hits retinal with a certain wavelength, the light excites the 
electron in the double bond of the pigment and changes its shape. When the 
shape of the pigment changes, the confirmation of the protein changes which 
opens up a channel in the rod cell of your eye. There's a whole chain of 
events that sends a signal to your brain to tell you what it is you saw. 
Light hitting from different angles affects the photoreceptor in different 
ways.

comments.text:
Pretend the light in the box is a billiard ball bouncing around the box 
extremely quickly. You then send a golf ball slowly through the box. If the 
box were empty, the golf ball would roll through in a straight line. 
However if the box has the billiard ball bouncing around in it, the golf 
ball will get hit and come out the other side with a different direction 
and/or momentum.

We're not dealing with billiard balls and golf balls, but the idea of 
interaction is similar. Only now, we can't just look at the golf ball, we 
have to actually poke it with something to check its state (because it's 
TINY.) We know that if we poke it, and the "golf ball" particle never 
interacted with the "billiard ball," we'll always poke it into its "dead" 
state. However, if it DID interact with the "billiard ball," our poke will 
force it into its "alive" state.
comments.author: Stephen Davis

comments.text:

unless the photon interacts with it, giving it a new spin.

However, it doesn't explain how we see light.... which is what the title is.
comments.author: Brill Pappin

comments.text:
Because before passing through the box the atom is in a superposition of 
two atomic states (dead or alive). This means that the odds of the atom 
being in one of the two states is changing in time (the atom can only be in 
this state if it's not being measured, see the Heisenberg principle of 
uncertainty) when the atom is measured it can't be in both states so the 
scientists (I imagine) have determined through experiments that the most 
likely to happen is the atom to become in the dead state when it hasn't 
interacted with a photon and the contrary if it has interacted.

comments.text:
All quantum systems, like an electron, or an atom, have multiple states 
(configurations of its properties) and superposition as a principle states 
that a physical system exists in partially in all its physical states. Yet, 
when we actually measure it, we only get the answer that the system is at 
one state. So when we talk about the wave-particle theory of light, this 
light has two states... waves or light. -- See the Heisenberg Uncertainty 
Principle.  At least that's how I think of it, I could be completely 
wrong... But I hope this helps﻿

comments.text:
"There is no way to say what the state of a system fundamentally is, only 
what the result of observations might be." These news pretty much throws 
the Heisenberg Uncertainty Principle out of the window, accomplishing what 
Einstein could not in a way: attempting to measure particles without 
subjecting them to probabilistic collapse due to the observer's effect. He 
even whipped out his E=MC^2 in a thought experiment to oppose it and it was 
no good. This technique has implications that we can observe what the heck 
someone else is doing and predict their actions without having to 
gamble(observer's effect) if it can be applied on a larger scale.

comments.author: Q Leo

comments.text:
Sontraid: Unless you're a physicist, QM is difficult to grasp regardless. 
Sure--Youtube videos, History Channel documentaries, and internet articles 
can give you a brief insight, but unless you can actually work and 
understand the formulas supporting QM (partial differential equations): you 
don't really understand much of anything, as Schrodinger's equation is the 
very basis for all QM interpretations. I've watched enough videos and read 
enough articles to act like I know something, but I really do not. I "know" 
that, given Schrodinger's equation, if ψsub1, which is simply a wave 
function, is a solution and some other wave function  ψsub2 is also a 
solution, then basic calculus tells us ψ=ψsub1+ψsub2: which is where 
superpositioning comes from (a particle being in two places at once)! I 
also "know" that because of the indefinite nature of the wave function ψ: 
we can only solve for the probability of finding a particle in a given 
location at time t. This means that regardless of how much physical 
information you know about an object, relative to Schrodinger's equation, 
the best we can hope for is still probabilities! This probabilistic 
approach is in bitter disagreement with classical mechanic's deterministic 
approach (aka everything can be known given the necessary data). This very 
consideration is what provoked Einstein to write the famous quote, "I, at 
any rate, am convinced that He [God] does not throw dice." And so yes, 
obviously, it helps to be vaguely (blindly in my case) versed in QM, as it 
gives you a context for many historical events and QM interpretations. I 
just hate it when people act like they understand QM in it's entirety, as 
I'm pretty sure physicists themselves are having a difficult time finding 
the correct interpretation of QM: assuming we're not missing pieces of the 
puzzle! (gravity or dark energy even! who knows. :p) If you're a physicist, 
I apologize, and consider this comment as a negligible refutation!

-Matthew W.
comments.author: Matthew wroblewski

comments.text:
+Velexia Ombra The only positive thing this video did for me was to make me 
curious about the idea of checking whether there was a photon in the box by 
sending atoms in some kind of superposition through the box. Maybe this is 
an example of "weak measurement" --- something I've seen mentioned in 
connection with trajectories averaged over many particles in a double-slit 
experiment. The idea of weak measurement seems to contradict the usual (or 
should I say old) assertion that interactions are frozen out if they would 
add or subtract less than the smallest relevant quantum energy transition. 
This also applies to energy equipartition in quantum statistical mechanics. 
If there is no freezing out of interactions, I don't see how any of that 
can be made to work. Even the black-body radiation would be affected.

In this case, only the statistics of subsequent measurement of the atoms is 
changed. Maybe the atoms end up heating or cooling the walls of the box 
very slightly in order to change the probabilities. I don't know.

Well, they won the Prize for this, so it ought to be something difficult. I 
guess the fact that I don't understand is natural.
comments.author: Ralph Dratman

comments.text:

this - not YouTube. If you never been taught in an academic setting, then 
you probably never applied these concepts or been using quantum numbers to 
solve quantum mechanics problems, and that is what makes the difference

comments.text:
Schrodinger's Cat was a critique of how ridiculous the theory of super 
position was, not an illustration of it.

As for everything else, he simply did not do anything but gloss over things 
in such a way that it explained nothing of value to anyone.

It's not that I don't enjoy his videos, this is just a critique of his 
video.  I think he could have done a better job here in actually explaining.
comments.author: Velexia Ombra

comments.text:
He explained: the difficulty of measuring protons, the experiment currently 
underway to try and resolve ( or rather go around this issue of protons 
becoming lost as soon as you detect them), then he made a joke about 
schrodinger's cat probably because its a crazy analogy about a cat being 
alive and dead simultaniously, in order to explain a weird concept called 
quantum mechanics- which is what super positioning a particle is in the 
realm of. and he did it in less than 3 min
